Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: See Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant (general principles of quiet enjoyment and landlord obligations); see also Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing tenant protections where conditions render premises untenantable); accord Massachusetts cases recognizing landlord duties to maintain premises and tenant remedies under state law.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations underscore landlord obligations to maintain safe and sanitary premises and to eliminate conditions that threaten health and safety, including the State Sanitary Code: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), which is implemented under the public health statutes, see M.G.L. c. 111, §127A and related provisions enabling enforcement of housing standards.

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations underscore landlord obligations to maintain safe and sanitary premises and to eliminate conditions that threaten health and safety, including the State Sanitary Code: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), which is implemented under the public health statutes, see M.G.L. c. 111, §127A and related provisions enabling enforcement of housing standards.

M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: The Massachusetts landlord–tenant statutory framework governing landlord obligations and tenant protections is found in M.G.L. c. 186 (general provisions governing tenancies), including provisions addressing landlord duties and remedies, and M.G.L. c. 239 (summary process) where applicable to possession disputes.

M.G.L. c. 239.proposition: The Massachusetts landlord–tenant statutory framework governing landlord obligations and tenant protections is found in M.G.L. c. 186 (general provisions governing tenancies), including provisions addressing landlord duties and remedies, and M.G.L. c. 239 (summary process) where applicable to possession disputes.

M.G.L. c. 93A \u00a7\u00a72, 11.proposition: See M.G.L. c. 93A §§2, 11; M.G.L. c. 186 §§14, 15B; M.G.L. c. 111 §127A; 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.; Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §15.4; Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (for general principle that substantial interference may give rise to tenant remedies).

M.G.L. c. 186 \u00a7\u00a714, 15B.proposition: See M.G.L. c. 93A §§2, 11; M.G.L. c. 186 §§14, 15B; M.G.L. c. 111 §127A; 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.; Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §15.4; Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (for general principle that substantial interference may give rise to tenant remedies).

Rogers v. Zakin, 327 Mass. 199 (1951).proposition: Rogers v. Zakin, 327 Mass. 199 (1951) (discussing tenant protections and landlord responsibilities) [example of Massachusetts courts addressing landlord-tenant obligations];
Rogers v. Zakin, 327 Mass. 199 (1951).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns probate law, specifically construction of a will, lapse of a residuary bequest, intestacy, and allocation/payment of federal estate and Massachusetts inheritance taxes. It does not involve any landlord-tenant relationship, tenant protections, or landlord responsibilities. Using this case as an example of Massachusetts courts addressing landlord-tenant obligations is inaccurate and out of context.
Rogers v. Zakin, 327 Mass. 199 (1951).relevant_excerpt: “The controversy in the case relates to the instructions of the judge that the share of the residue of which Annie Hillard Pitt was named residuary legatee and which now passes to the next of kin of the testatrix shall be applied to the payment of the Federal estate tax and the Massachusetts inheritance tax… The inheritance taxes on the estate and on all legacies, both special and residuary, must therefore be paid from the residue.”

Commonwealth v. Slayton, 350 Mass. 104 (.proposition: Commonwealth v. Slayton, 350 Mass. 104 (1965) (recognition of statutory public health enforcement authority under M.G.L. c. 111) [cited for public-health enforcement context];
Commonwealth v. Slayton, 350 Mass. 104 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Commonwealth v. Giles (mis-cited as Slayton) concerns the scope of the Massachusetts perjury statute, G.L. c. 268, § 1, particularly whether false testimony before the Crime Commission (created by resolve) is punishable as perjury. It does not interpret or apply M.G.L. c. 111, nor does it address statutory public health enforcement authority or any public health context. Therefore, it does not support a proposition about recognition of enforcement authority under c. 111.
Commonwealth v. Slayton, 350 Mass. 104 (.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that when the defendant was examined before the commission under oath, he was then ‘required by law to take an oath’ and could be prosecuted under the inclusive language of the second clause (see fn. 3 at point [C]). We reach this conclusion because of the breadth of the statutory language. The ordinary meaning of that language would put any person on notice that his conduct will be criminal if he wilfully lies under oath before a body such as the Crime Commission.”

Deutsche Bank Nat\u2019l Trust Co. v. Ma.raw_text: Deutsche Bank Nat’l Trust Co. v. Mahan, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 1023 (2014)
Deutsche Bank Nat\u2019l Trust Co. v. Ma.proposition: Deutsche Bank Nat’l Trust Co. v. Mahan, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 1023 (2014) (discussing landlord/owner obligations in property contexts) [persuasive for property-owner duties];

Hennessey v. Town of Lexington, 22 Mass..raw_text: Hennessey v. Town of Lexington, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 798 (1986)
Hennessey v. Town of Lexington, 22 Mass..proposition: Hennessey v. Town of Lexington, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 798 (1986) (addressing nuisance, public safety and municipal enforcement) [relevant to safety and nuisance concepts].
